markdownRemark.html:
Score: 87.5

independent.co.uk  (WEB - en-US)

The website for The Independent, a major British news outlet founded as a neutral counterbalance to the often highly opinionated U.K. press. In 2016, The Independent became the first British newspaper to publish online only.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The Independent’s ownership, which is not disclosed on the site, is predominantly divided among three stakeholders: Evgeny Lebedev, Sultan Mohamed Abuljadayel, and Justin Byam Shaw.

Lebedev, who The Financial Times reported in July 2017 owns 41 percent of the paper, is a Russian-born British businessman who also owns the Evening Standard, a free London daily newspaper, and London Live, a local London television station. The New Statesman wrote in July 2011 that Lebedev’s wealth is drawn from his father, Alexander Lebedev, a Russian banking oligarch and one-time KGB spy who now finances the Russian opposition newspaper Novaya Gazeta. Evgeny Lebedev acquired his stake in The Independent in March 2010.

Abuljadayel owns 30 percent of The Independent, according to The Financial Times. The Guardian reported in August 2017 that he is a manager at NCB Capital, the investment arm of the Saudi government-owned bank NCB. The other major stakeholder, Shaw, is an entrepreneur and philanthropist who owns 26 percent of The Independent, according to The Financial Times. Shaw serves as chairman of the paper’s parent company, ESI Media.

The Independent was founded as an upmarket paper claiming to be free from political bias. Both Lebedev’s and Abuljadayel’s purchases of stakes in the paper raised questions about whether the outlet’s independence might be compromised. According to the BBC, Abuljadayel’s purchase was structured so that he had no place on the company’s board, a step aimed at allaying concerns over possible Saudi influence.

Independent.co.uk runs advertisements and sells subscriptions. After years of declining circulation and revenue, in March 2016 The Independent became the first major British newspaper to cease print publication and become online-only. This proved a successful strategy. According to the BBC, the paper went from recording losses of £17 million in 2012 to being profitable and valued at approximately £100 million in 2017. The BBC also noted that “One third of revenues at the title come from the US, where the anti-Trump wave has been a boon.”

The Independent also publishes the online-only outlet indy100.com, which presents stories from The Independent in briefer form.

Content

Main content sections on the site include News, Politics, Sport, Culture, Video, Long Reads, and Voices. The site also has a section called InFact, which consists of articles that fact-check claims made by politicians and others.

Articles frequently focus on U.K. and U.S. politics, Brexit, science, education, business, and technology. Typical stories have run under headlines such as “Facebook hit with huge fine for failing to protect its users’ privacy;” “European Parliament votes to ban single-use plastics in bid to tackle pollution;” and “Catholic Church launches its own version of Pokémon Go where children catch saints.”

The Independent has described itself as being “committed, since its foundation, to the causes of social justice, European unity, the environment and free markets.” Although The Independent launched with the explicit goal of being politically centrist, in the U.K. it is generally considered a center-left newspaper, particularly in its Voices (opinion) section, which has published articles such as  “Brexit and Trump have proved that lies are more attractive than facts.”

Credibility

The Independent regularly conducts original, fact-based reporting and often breaks stories. Headlines accurately represent content. Exclusive stories in October 2018 included the first foreign media interview of Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan and an article revealing that at least 575 buildings across the U.K. are at risk of collapse in the event of a fire or gas explosion.

The site features an extensive, accessible Code of Conduct detailing its editorial standards. “It is our primary endeavour to publish information that is accurate and will not mislead readers,” the code states. “All substantial material and quotes should be attributed correctly.” Addressing the issue of sourcing, the code directs the outlet’s journalists: “If an investigative story or any allegation of wrongdoing depends on the word of a single source you should try and get it corroborated by at least one other, unconnected and trustworthy source.”

The site has two dedicated opinion sections: Voices and Final Say. Final Say is a section dedicated to The Independent’s campaign to “demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.” Voices is the site’s general opinion section.

Opinionated articles are typically published in one of these two sections. However, many news articles have a note appended to the bottom stating: "The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal," linking to a petition. Although this approach could be seen as constituting a blending of news and opinion, NewsGuard has determined that The Independent is upfront in disclosing its political mission concerning Brexit, and generally provides balanced coverage of the issue, often quoting pro-Brexit officials and activists.

The Independent has been accused of being biased in favor of Saudi Arabia because of Sultan Abuljadayel’s ownership stake. British political magazine Private Eye reported in October 2018 that, one year after Abuljadayel’s purchase of his 30 percent stake in The Independent, “there have already been reports of the ‘chill effect’ on Saudi stories.”

However, the site regularly runs articles that are unflattering to the Saudi government. For example, a March 2018 story reported that peace groups were opposing a U.S. arms sale to Saudi Arabia. An August 2018 story was headlined “Saudi coalition airstrike hits school bus killing dozens of children in Yemen.” The site also has extensively covered the murder of journalist and Saudi regime critic Jamal Khashoggi, including claims that the Saudi royal family ordered the murder.

The Independent has a dedicated corrections page and its editorial code of conduct states, “It is the responsibility of every department head, but also everyone working for the Group, whatever their status, to ensure that you follow up anything that might appear to you to be incorrect.” The site regularly publishes corrections, which generally appear in italics below articles.

Transparency

Articles on independent.co.uk typically provide their authors’ names and Twitter handle, as well as a link to a brief biography. The site does not identify its top editors and does not disclose its ownership.

Advertisements are distinguished from editorial content.

The Independent did not respond to two emails seeking comment about the site’s lack of disclosure about its ownership and site leaders.

History

The Independent, launched in 1986, was the first new major British national newspaper since the founding of The Sun, 22 years earlier. The Independent was the first U.K. paper to adopt the a more compact format, in 2003, and the first to forego print entirely.  

Written by:
Bron Maher

Edited by:
Anna-Sophie Harling Eric Effron
